_comment: Created by ianb on 27/04/2015 18:08:21 using v2.5
title: Has the number of people who finished a course of treatment increased and how successful was the treatment?
analysis_commentary:
Successfully finishing a course of treatment is only one outcome for those referred to IAPT. Other outcomes include: declining or dropping out of treatment, being referred to another service, not being suitable for IAPT treatments or dying before they reach an outcome. The number of people successfully finishing a course of treatment has generally increased over time. In 2014-15 Q2 this was 114,697, roughly 40,000 more than 2011-12 Q1.

The proportion of finished treatments that showed reliable improvement, which means they achieved significant improvements in their symptoms but they did not achieve the technical definition of recovery (shown later) has increased slightly over time. Data on reliable recovery started collection in 2013-14 Q1, at this time it was 58.1%. By 2014-15 Q2 this had increased slightly to 61.3%. For all data points, more than half of finished treatment courses showed a reliable improvement in symptoms.
data_source: Health & Social Care Information Centre, Improving Access to Psychological Therapies Data Set
